unit_learning_outcomes.description: Critically evaluate the diverse impacts of global economic integration, especially on the state’s governing powers over the economy through contemporary conceptual approaches and empirical case studies
Deepen knowledge of the  policy dimensions  of global economic integration.
Analyse the rise of new state and non-state global and international power actors brought about globalisation.
Convey an understanding of the major debates and contemporary issues raised by the study of International Political Economy.
Adopt a macro (big picture) perspective on economic globalisation’s impacts, which integrates theory and empirical evidence

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to MIntRel or PGDipIntRel or GradDipIntRel or MIntCommMIntRel or MIntBusMIntRel or MIntRelMIntTrdeComLaw or MTransInterMIntRel or MConfInt or MIntTrdeComLaw or MPPP or GradDipPP or GradCertIntRel or MPPPMIntRel

assessments.description: Provide an analysis on a topic
Students are required to demonstrate knowledge of key concepts, debates, substantive issues examined in the unit.

There is an expectation that all students will read the designated readings before coming to lectures and tutorials. They will be expected to contribute to class discussions and activities based on their preparation
Write an essay utilising the required readings in the unit and your own independent research.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Fully online/virtual
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.description: This unit provides an advanced introduction to the study of international political economy, and to develop students’ research, analytical and problem-solving skills. The unit examines the key questions, concepts, findings and controversies in the study of global economic integration and interdependence and considers the role of the state and non-state actors in shaping the international system.
data.title: International Political Economy
